gained: I have learned to manage groups of people and to be more forward about my emotions. Also, how to talk to other people about emotions.
Creativity grows with practice
Learning how to talk to others & express myself
It has helped me with my shyness and social anxiety a lot by making me speak in groups as a player at first. Now I DM a small group, a feat I thought impossible just a few years ago.

Never split the party. While true my serious answer would be creative problem-solving. I typically play a utility rogue. As I’m a handy-man of sorts IRL. It helps find a different approach to problem-solving. Plus getting a “sure why not” is always a nice day. Whether at work or in game. Next would be socializing. I can be an antagonistic person ,:3 not always intentionally, but I can rub people the wrong way. And it goes the same with a DnD party. Some get along some are here to just have fun. Others max-min so it’s a delicate balancing act finding where you fit with each other person and their play style.
I learned how to look at something through someone else’s shoes it had helped me realise that I need some more order in how I plan out my life
Connection to a great community and a game system that lets you practice for real life
I've just gained a fun hobby to do on weekends
Critical thinking, creative outlet, problem solving, expanded understanding of human behavior and abstract thinking
Creativity
Creativity
Playing provides a lot of opportunities to practice various forms of interaction and performance skills, and as a DM you end up researching a huge number of extremely obscure facts.
Compassion to stick to a project and improvisation
Be in the moment of things, if you stay in the back and think about things you will be left behind sometimes.
The true treasure is friendship

I've gained a circle of good friends that will support me in tough times. We meet regularly, ask each other about everything, help each other out if someone has troubles. It's a small community where we share a common interest.
To embrace your own faults
How to manage time (being a DM requires allotting yourself enough time to build dungeons and make characters that make sense).
Every experience my character goes through, I go through. It gives you some life lessons without actually being there.
A lot of skill in storytelling

Tabletop RPGs have certainly helped me with taking the edge off of my social anxiety and through live streaming sessions, have even helped with my public speaking. I don't know for certain if it has helped me make any friends, as noted above, but my friendships are certainly stronger with the people I game with.
Critical thinking, problem solving, improvisation, acting, mathematics, public speaking
Whenever you weave a complicated web, the things that stand out to other people aren't always the things that stand out to yourself. People will surprise you.
Confidence in my own actions
Cooperation. You have your story to tell but you also have to support others in telling their own story.
Sense of adventure, closer friendship with people I play with.
I've developed pretty good improv skills.
Refining my ability to multitask

I am now able to make small calculations in my head way faster, I learned public speaking, including describing objects and places and my english skills have grown a lot (I'm not a native speaker) and my vocabulary has expanded very much.
Improvisation, time management, improved reading comprehension and recall

I play TTRPGs as a result of playing both videogames and doing theatre for 8 years. All the skills about improv or keeping cool (emotional skills) came from 2 fields, but weren't originated in TTRPGs. To be fair though, D&D has helped me from a storytelling standpoint to understand how to craft a well paced story
To deal with people that have conficting interests
Quick math and planning
Work/life balance
Fun
I have learned a lot of team building and story building skills
Lots of things, ranging from big ones like empathy to stuff like silly accents and characterization.
It’s just fun
I've gained a hobby. TTRPGs have enhanced skills I learned elsewhere, but I would hardly say it's taught me anything.
These games are a great creative outlet and helped me learn how to express myself.

In addition to other minor gains, I learned through ttrpg's very early in life the ability to understand and support people going through changes concerning gender, sexuality, emotional states, etc. Which is a rare trait that some people never gain in their entire life. It helped me understand that like in ttrpg's, some people want to play something they are not in the immediate moment, something they would like to be. (real story, I had a trans friend that used ttrpg's to get a feel for their desired gender, and because of ttrpg's decided to go through with the change)
It allowed me to fully express myself, and try out alternate personalities. It really helped me in coming out as both non-binary and bisexual.

D&D is a fun way to connect with friends and flex my creative writing muscles. It has helped me strengthen relationships, unwind during stressful periods, and improve my writing and improvisation skills.
Creativity
I'm a teacher. I sometimes use mechanics from the game to help create interesting lessons and activities in regards to my mythology unit.
There's always more than one way to solve a problem, and just cause it's not the way you thought, doesn't mean it's stupid
entertainment
Nothing ever goes as planned
Creativity
To listen better, learn to say yes more and be open to other people's ideas.
Social problem solving, group management, and narrative verisimilitude.

I've learned that people are generally looking for an excuse to hang out. It can feel overwhelming as an adult to make time for friends and organize a meeting. Which makes it so you dont want to bother yoyrself or others unless its worth it but hanging with your friends is worth it always.
I'm better at making characters now
Fun
Critical thinking / working puzzles
The ability to channel my creativity in a productive way

It has flowed easily into my career as project manager. Part of the reason I enjoy DMing is the fact that I have grown the skills to schedule and manage everyone's schedules, along with learning to how motivate and tailor experiences to different types of people.
Confidence in myself as a storyteller and as a person.
Amazing friends that I play with, generally made my life 100 times better than it was before.
Confidence in myself when speaking to an audience.
There are more like minded people than you think!
A new hobby and community
The joy that doing stupid voices and being silly with your friends

Table top gaming has been a great way to explore perspectives and topics that I can’t in real life. It has helped me develop empathy and has made it easier for me to connect with people outside of table top gaming.
The ability to quickly react to situations

How to agree to disagree gracefully, how to work with very different people to reach a mutual goal, and when it is better to allow others to learn from mistakes that in real life would be very painful if not out right lethal.
I have learned to have confidence in my decisions and be less afraid to do something sub-optimally.
If I can find the patience to put up with my players, I can deal with just about anyone.
Its as a DM, life is a unpredictable mess and that plans not allways works as intended. It’s best during those situations to just improvise
Better critical thinking skills
Writing skills
Better group management and team solving skills
Tons of fun
Improv, speaking in front of others more confidently, organizational skills, managing schedules/people,
Friends and a lifelong hobby

The ability to socialize over things that I enjoy, while learning to disregard people who would judge me for the things I like.  How to look at the world from both sides of the spectrum, such as the views of the player, but also the views of the monsters/villains they oppose.  How to better make choices socially and statistically that will yield the results that I find most beneficial.   How to analyze and understand statistical data through the dice rolling.  How to write more neatly.  I learned a lot about socialization also that people want to put themselves, or in the vernacular... be in a party... with good aligned people more than they want to be with evil aligned.  That alignment in a political spectrum doesn't have to be Lawful/Stupid, and that there are degrees to belief from mild support to outright zealotry.  I could go on... I think you get the idea.
That if something isn't working as intended, to be open and communicative about it.
Think on my feet and conversation skills
How to feel more comfortable with myself. Also how to adapt to changing situations better.

DMing gives me an outlet for the creativity I feel I can't put anywhere else; I feel a lot of pressure when I write or make art to be better than everyone I see online, and my work only feels good enough in the personal setting of my D&D group.
In general having found something else to be passionate about in life is always great especially when I can share it with my friends and gain more friends!
creativity, fun with friends outside of gaming on pc/online
How to compromise with others well and how to synergize with those around me very well.
Compromise
A fun outlet.
Mostly creative writing and improvisational skills. Some organizational skills as well.
I'm much faster at simple math now, namely small integer addition.
while i do not feel that i have LEARNED many skills, do feel that many of the social and improv skills that i have have been improved thorugh playing tabletop RPGs
Emphaty
I think I was pretty well-socialized prior to playing TTRPGs, instead I'd say being a DM has taught me more about organization, quick thinking and storytelling
The life my wife and I lead is somewhat isolationist because of scheduling, but D&D allows me to schedule built-in friend-group time for us, and it's awesome.
It's a hell of a lot of fun and a great way to avoid thinking about the crushing amount of schoolwork I gotta still get done.

The biggest thing has been improved public speaking skills. As a soon-to-be schoolteacher I will certainly use the preparation and speaking abilities cultivated through TTRPGs to help me in my career.

Social skills are a big one. Problem solving, scheduling. Plus, a whole freaking lot of friends I wouldn't have made otherwise. These people live states and countries away from me (USA). Additionally, I write homebrew stuff for D&D 5e, so it is a great creative outlet as well.
column9: social problem solving planning friendship creativity|

gained: To not be ashamed of doing things i love
The best thing I have learned from dnd is empathy and teamwork
Ive learned to step out of my comfort zone more, and I am able to share all of my stories and characters with my friends

multitasking. strategic thinking. short and long term memory.  ability to pull data from various sources and arrive at a single outcome. example, What is my To Hit score?:   strength + skill + advantages + buffs + racial advantages + items + situational advantages   lots of different sources and types to remember and to check, and then munge into a final discrete number, need to do it quickly and accurately.   that particular type of exercise helps tremendously for tech type jobs.
Negotiation skills

Problem solving skills, working together as a team, (personally) D&D has helped me with a lot of emotional  disconnection  And depression; when I started playing it helped me realize that there is a fun side to life.

It gives me an emotional outlet that is outside talking it out. Also, sometimes it's nice to have a different inner voice than your regular one. I've definitely had a conversation with my favorite characters telling me to be brave.
Dnd is fun
I can get over performance anxiety, I've learned not to be the center of attention,  I've bolstered my creativity, made new friends, and have a great many stories to tell.
How to manage groups. Expectations. How to tell good stories. How to negotiate in relationships.
It's helped me process how to express myself in more diplomatic ways, to exercise the story writer parts of my brain that help me understand character motivations of the real people in my life.
Making stories happen is one of my greatest needs

I credit rpgs for a great deal of my social ability and success in my career. The ability to work in teams, to solve problems and most importantly to learn and model empathy and how to care for my fellows has been essential for my personal life and professional success. I am a better person, and hopefully a better employee, boss, friend and husband because of gaming.

Confidence. I have learned to speak to people confidently. I have learned how to command attention from a room full of people. I have learned to speak clearly and thoughtfully. I have learned to empathize with others, how others feel and think. I have learned to put the needs of others before myself. Overall, I have made many friends during my gaming sessions, and it has helped me develop as a fully functional human being who can interact with others on a day to day basis.
Most people are looking to connect with one another, and love to reveal something of themselves in every character they play.
Group problem solving skills, statistical anslysis
A creative outlet that I never had before.
A new hobby and some new friends.
Gainesville confidence
a place to relax and not worty about the rest of the world. also it’s provided a place for me to come a little out of my shell and not worry about making an ass of myself

Playing TTRPG's has given me and my friends a super fun and _creative_ way to hang out. The imagination I used to have as a kid has started to come back which is incredible! In general I have a more positive view of going out and doing things because everything in life is kind of an adventure. Seeing a character struggle but in the end succeed is also motivational.
Improvising, 'presenting', an understanding for rulesets or systems
Seeing things from other perspectives. Problem solving.
Conflict resolution
Vocabulary, math, theater skills, improved critical thinking
I learned how to work with others better, and improved my character writing skills.
I am THE BEST at running meetings. Everyone's always surprised, but it's years of DMing that taught me how to make people listen and take turns.
That the universe is infinite and I am only limited by the rules I create for myself.
That anyone can use their imagination and have a good time, no matter who they are or what they usually like
Strategy, Teamwork, Creative Writing, Organization, and a variety of artistic abilities.
A better understand of what outcomes will be caused by actions
Strategy and how to improv
Improvisational skills, and better storytelling skills.

A sense of imagination and creativity that I don't think I would have.  As an adult there aren't really many ways to let your mind have fun, but D&D is so fantastic in that it thrives on letting your mind out of its box to see and experience so many different things.  Its been like therapy for me.
Organising people do focus on one particular task (i.e. playing the game)
Creating genuine characters
Friendship, social skills, empathy, definitely empathy, very much so empathy
Friends for life, an ex-wife, public speaking & presentation skills, improvisation/winging it/fake it till you make it, love for real life adventure, love for the great outdoors.
Helps me understand other viewpoints than my own, especially as a create NPCs, especially villains, that have varied motivations and viewpoints.

I have learned a lot of writing skills both as 3.  Purely as a DM, I have greatly increased my improv skills - thinking on my feet, and trying to keep a plotline realistic when my players do something unexpected. I don't know if playing has helped me learn any emotional skills, but you certainly get to practice them!  Also, it's good practice for your poker face when your players throw a wrench into your plans... or fall right into a really stupid trap.  It's great watching your friends have fun.
How to craft a story.
A greater interest in history and geography

I gained a friend that I've had now for 15+ years. We have never met in person but talk daily. I have learned to become a better writer and to not judge a person or a situation too quickly. Better to assess before making a final decision.
Basic math (fast addition, subtraction), love of reading (starting with fantasy novels and expanding from there)
How to improvise
Entertainment
I've gained an excuse to hang out with friends and fun.
Ability to look at thing from multiple perspectives.  In real life, this means I can understand and empathize with people who don't agree with me.
Had a good time with my friends and an outlet for energy and creativity.
It is ok to be goofy, say yes and, be open to new ideas, team dynamics, plot hooks, and never know where creativity is going to come from
Perspective is not universal. What is obvious to one person will not be so to another
Creative thinking

They have helped lower my social inhibitions, breaking me out of my shell. They have also helped me learn how to respond to people and situations in interesting and engaging ways AND helped me think critically and creatively when tackling a problem.
How to be creative, and take risks.
I just helps me get my mind off things. A nice little bit of escapism can go a long way.
Purpose
A good outlet for my creative thinking
Everything?
I feel that since playing role playing games, I have been able to develop and strengthen friendships in more profound ways than I was easily able to before.

That strangers aren't as judgemental as you think, especially if you're doing the same thing. There's something very authentic about adults all agreeing to be elves and wizards and aliens with each other.
Improvisational skills, enjoyment of a game with friends, more creativity, improved interpersonal skills
In a world where friends are scattered across the globe and don’t have much reason to get together, TTRPGs present a space to hang out and be creative together even when bedridden.
It's a creative outlet that let me appreciate art, writing and creativity in general. It has gained me a lot of friends and social skills in general.
writing and improv
I've gained a group of online friends I can chat with for a few hours every week despite being separated from them in real life.
How to work to achieve a common goal, how to settle disputes.
That You can certainly try. Brings out a different part of me that likes to be challenged.

Working with groups, conflict resolution, creativity, critical analysis (reading & interrupting rules, build, combos), storytelling, public speaking, leadership when GMing, better writing skills, & oddly enough how to be a better parent.
I’ve learned to appreciate what it offers to a group of people, the expansive creativity is what people want to express and rpg/ttrpg let us do that.
Storytelling is a vehicle for emotional processing, which is awesome. But prepping for RPGs also incorporates a whole lot of planning, time (and people) management, and math.
Confidence.
Collaboration, non linear problem solving, communication, emotional openness, willingness to accept outside viewpoints and perspectives.
How to keep mass information organized, storytelling, event organization, creative writing, problem solving,
Comfortable speaking in front of a group

Empathy. If I want to play a character well, I tend to look more at the people around me. What starts off as inspiration to build an imaginary character blossoms into better understanding of how people feel and think.
Good times and laughs. Love the adventure of it

Confidence in talking with people I've just met, asking leading questions to get to know someone better, patience for other people's decision making processes, and a slight increase in being willing to take risks (only small, that shit is scary).
How to better schedule events, both socially and professionally.How to be more transparent in communication
Exciting Hobby To Do With Unfit Friends

RPGs are an incredible creative outlet. For someone like me, who had severe depression, finding the hobby was like discovering a whole new world. I wholeheartedly believe that D&D played an important part in my recovery and self-improvement.

Truly amazing stories coupled with weekly social gatherings. A loving wife, a massive collection of minis we really don't have room for (but I'm going to keep growing anyways), and of course a fascination with world building and storytelling. D&D is a creative, chaotic outlet in an otherwise ordered and predictable life pattern.
Finding focus and inspiration to write
Tempering expectations
to have fun even if things are considered weird or embarrassing. do what makes you happy, not what makes others happy.
I now know how to be a cat person.

From DM-ing you learn very quickly to account for other people’s feelings and resolve conflicts when that occurs. I have also massively boosted improvisational skills and making good, educated decisions under pressure.
Experience of tactics in a fantasy environment
Creativity
Confidence
Teamwork, Thinking things though, multitasking

Working in groups, analysing hypothetical situations for responses, challenging my own ideas of the world, following systems/rules to a desired outcome, storytelling, logic based on differing perspectives and information, a reason to hang out with old friends,
Confidence around strangers and in larger groups, organisational skills
Lots of problem solving and team building! More creative thinking in general as well
To not take things so seriously, a playful jab is just that.
Consistent positive social interaction
storytelling skills. Creating interesting worlds and characters, what does work and doesn't.
How to see things from the perspective of another and how the reality others face shape them despite there lack of control over such situations.
That you never have the answer to everything, life or your players will do the unexpected
Anticipation makes everything sweeter.

A vivid imagination, an opportunity to communicate with people on just on a social let's grab a beer level but deeper. I am friends with people I might have not met otherwise and we share unique in-game memories and a strong connection!
How to describe emotions and feelings; getting to know myself better through my characters.
Ways to write characters better and make them more believable and more problem solving skills
More chance to use my creative skills.
Game design
Human interaction is not dead or dying, you simply have to find a worth while may of spending it that fosters that interaction.
How to be more comfortable dealing with situations you dont expect. Improv is king
Not to quash peoples ideas. Even a simple thought can mean a lot someone. Take serious consideration and don't be afraid to tell people You can certainly try in and out of game.
Finding a new outlet to find new friends which has been a struggle as an adult.
A renewed imagination.
I have gained a community of supportive friends.
Mathematics, vocabulary, cooperation and teambuilding, cartography,  Reading other peoples emotions and expressing my own, speaking in different voices
Don't prioritize the happiness of others over your own; take care of yourself before you take care of others
A creative outlet
How to meet people, and worldbuilding/storytelling/acting techniques
Empathy
A better understanding of math and probabilities, as well as several very important friendships
how to adapt and inverate, how to improvise on the spot
Conflict resolution

I have learned that sometimes (most of the time) people will have varying opinions, and different solutions to problems that you may not agree with, but if you take the time to talk with them and work it out, you can come to a compromise that everyone will be happy with.
My players are idiots
Having a weekly meeting with friends has helped my mental health significantly
Being more confident to do what I love. And if I' making a fool of myself by doing it. That is ok, cause I enjoy it.^^
How to cooperate as a team while taking on a viewpoint other than my own has been incredibly helpful. Even just the teamwork alone.
My players are awful at Roleplay, so while i'd love to do those things, they can't hold a conversation in character.
None -- just fun with friends
A closer bond with my friends, as well as slightly better social awareness.
Almost anything you can think of
That there are different kinds of creativity a person can possess.
I’m autistic. It’s helped me be more sociable, and it’s great to have a game that leans straight into my strengths.
New ways to have fun with friends
Tactic, negotiation, a bit of English (I am french) , friend for life

I feel like I've learned to manage interactions with people better. The character/story moments of playing haven't necessarily contributed to personal growth, but the more logistical side of things has definitely helped. Like learning to adjust schedules, coordinate groups of people and the like.

I find it quite interesting to see the difference in how people act in real life vs. how they play a character in a tabletop rpg. I suppose the thing I've learned from my relatively short time playing these games is that people really enjoy letting loose and being free from expectations when they create a character for a made up world that can do whatever they want.
Patience, mostly.
Never split the party. Having others to lean on can be good
Friendship
Guiding user experience. Understanding the differences between what I see vs. what the party sees has been helpful in both my teaching and other customer service roles I have held.
Developed more confidence speaking publicly
Pain heals. Chicks dig scars. Glory… lasts forever
I strengthened my bonds with some friends, made new ones, distressed from life, met my first gf (and ex-gf) through the gf of one of my new friends.TLDR strengthened and made new friendships.
A new sense of imagination and creativity that I thought was lost with childhood
I've learned that not everything is meant be be won, and most things you must work for
As a player, I learned not everyone works well together. As a DM, I learned a whole lot about why the world is the way it is and how it came to be that way, both geologically and people-logically.
I became a more well rounded, social individual. Without roleplay, I would have receded into asocial obscurity.
Social skills, public speaking, entertainment
Confidence in my creativity, ability to connect with more diverse groups of people, lots of work on my social anxiety
Being a DM, I have learned how to better improvise when things go unexpectedly and adapt to situations. This has proved helpful in my personal life as well.
improvisation
Storytelling, Improvisational Collaboration
To announce your reaction before the dm can ask for initiative

Planning and group scheduling! Keeping communication lines open with the purpose of making sure everyone has the information they need to act, in time to decide what to do, to minimize wasted time/effort and maximize fun.
Many good friends, better social skills, i think it helped my problem solvings skills and mademe better at looking for a creative solution to a problem.
Never split the party (things are better if you keep your friends around you)
Game design theory
New friends who only talk to me once a Week/ Month.
Organizational skills. Communicative skills. Writing skills (story structure) and improv.
Conflict management between myself and others, and between others.
That you shouldn’t try and seduce a dragon
The value in self-expression

I don't think much about my D&D games bleeds over to my normal life. It's a hobby that I enjoy and like the rest of my hobbies playing is fun which leads to general happiness. Beyond that though my games do not affect my life outside the game at all.
Creativity
I got an escape from reality and depression that helped me overcome it by being able to be whoever I wanted.
Better math skills, critical thinking, and creativity
It’s a fun hobby where I get to be creative.
Public speaking, assertive communication, fun and meaning and creative expression
Better improvisational skills

I don’t think I gained or learned social skills or the like simply because I developed those through other activities I engaged in before I started playing DnD (ie sports) but I’d say the incredible experiences and great times I gained by playing with my friends are invaluable memories that I will cherish for the rest of my life.
It's helped me make new friends, and maybe might've improved my social skills. This is a small thing, but I also feel it's helped my vocabulary.
Creative writing, voice acting, game design
Writing
I got to reconnect with old classmates and enjoy time with shared activities.
Improved ability to improvise and adapt to unexpected situations.
An outlet to creativity and writing, which was missing from my life for a few years now.
How to improvise
Creative writing
Good times with friends and a great way to express my creativity.
Story writing, such as what makes a compelling story, or why is this more interesting than that?
Mostly expressing myself through characters

I met my fiancé through D&D, so there's that! But TTRPGs have helped me get past difficult struggles I had in life, just by being such an in-depth distraction, but as well as something that I did with people and friends that care about me.
It's good to prepare for the expected outcome, but prepare for the possibilty that nothing goes as planned. Be ready for anything. Also, nearly anything can be a weapon.

a fun way to meet with friends and spend time with them, a chance to be part of a story rather than an observer to it. It has confirmed me in my belief hat broad-strokes plans are better than detailed plans because you will end up having to improvise anyway when (not if) something goes wrong.
Creativity, passion, a love for the written word.
A constructive hobby that allows me to flex the creative side of my brain.
Spending time with existing friends, learning more about them. Started playing as an adult
a sense of fitting in, creating a fun enviroment for freinds that we can all enjoy
That it's ok to be me, especially when I'm pretending to be someone else.
Conflict resolution, scheduling, how to communicate what I need, and a consistent reason for my friend group to maintain itself.
Improv skills first and foremost.
Various problem-solving and teamworking skills.
Practice dealing with disagreements and personality clashes.
A lot to be honest. D&D has taught me to make friends, boosted my self confidence and has overall changed my life for the better.
Social skills, a friend group, a hobby
Inhibitions are lame if they get in the way of fun
How to get into character
More patience and much more honest communication.
Improv
An appreciation for the theory of game design.

I learned that a close friend wasn't really a friend at all, he was just using me because I was convenient, we had the same sense of humor and worked together. The act of requiring him to engage in any work outside of face-to-face fun, like putting together a character sheet, caused him to show his true colors. Without D&D I probably would have invested significantly more time and money into a relationship that was never going to pay off.
Creative thinking
It has allowed me to stay connected to friends that I may have fallen out of contact otherwise.
Public speaking and improv. Confidence
Dealing with different Personalities
Creative outlet
New way to have fun.
An excuse to hang out with some friends
The ability to view events from multiple moral viewpoints
Planning, organization, confidence, public speaking
Good stories and communal experiences
Theory of mind thinking skills
Better understanding of emotions, both my own and those of others.
Social skills, ability to work with a group, and close friendships
How to just relax and get involved in what's happening right now
friends!
Fun times with friends and family.
Math proficiency is extremely high due to TTRPG's.
DMing
Less what I've gained, and more what it has done. When I play I can work through problems I've had or relieve stress that I've had by what and who I'm playing.
The ability to present all options or approaches to a problem in a neutral manner and with minimal bias.
Fun memories
It’s been a good social activity to make friends and get to know people such as coworkers
Improv and team building skills
Faster math skills
To be flexible and know that not everything in life goes the way you expect it to be
Another creative outlet
How to manage player expectations
I’ve learned some solid organizational skills, such as excel usage and the ability to get a group of people together on different schedules.
How to organize groups of people around a busy schedule. Meeting strangers, befriending them and encouraging them to roleplay.
Good learning tool for how gray life's choices can be.
Analytical skills, teamwork, and compromise. I’ve also improved my writing skills and creative thinking.
Found a creative outlet, I thought I couldn’t be creative but the love I have for my characters makes me more confident in myself
How to give voice to the various aspects of my personality, both in-game and in real life.
Improvisation, mostly. How to think on my feet better.
Learned alternative ways of writing and world building
Organization, confidence
Strategising, planning your course of actions, creative thinking and problem solving.
Keep it simple stupid
More confidence in public speaking
Theater of the Mind
I've been able to channel the more assertive and charismatic characters to adopt those traits IRL
How to set up realistic expectations and how to deal with toxic people
Sometimes it's okay to sit down and be someone else, but all in all, you need to be true to you.
How to remember and analyze rule sets.
Confidence in my decisions and not needing to be perfect.
A bookshelf and a firm grasp of probability math.
How to play DND, a new Hobbie, a greater appreciation for the arts.

I've answered neutral to all of these questions because I'd say I've already been doing well in those regards, e.g social skills, emotional skills, etc. I know that probably won't help much with your data gathering, and I'm sorry. Hopefully this bit of a write in will make up for it: I've engrossed myself in the community of DnD, and I've seen and heard so many stories of DnD doing exactly this for other people, and have gotten feedback and seen first hand players coming out of their shells and becoming more talkative and excited and social. Dungeons and Dragons is a very powerful tool, and one I'm glad I get to share with other people.
I learned how to tell stories more engagingly, learned how to be more comedic and well versed, and mostly how to bring out the best in others.
How to let go and stop worrying out how other people perceive me.
Creativity, writing skills, math (specifically probability), and presentation skills.
Public speaking, storytelling, on the fly creativity

Playing role playing games has instilled a desire in me to learn about why things are the way that they are. As a DM, creating a believable world and retaining the verisimilitude of things can seem an impossible feat or even terrifying, at first. A land full of monsters and magic couldn't possibly be real, let alone the possibility to maintain that illusion of realness for the other people that you're playing with. Yet, even in our own world, as blasé as it might appear, there are things that many people willingly accept as reality without necessarily knowing why they are the way that they are. The anatomy of plants and their evolutionary paths and why certain plants grow the way that they do or look the way that they do is a perfect example of that. There are botanist out there in the world, but most day to day people don't find a strong inkling to go leisurely study a topic like that, a topic mind you that I never would have broached if not for a desire brought on by my inclusion of some cool fungus monsters in a D&D game. Role playing games, to me, are a window to a fantastical world, but sometimes they behave like a mirror and reflect back some truth of the fantastical nature of our own world and our own collective history back to the players. That's a very long winded way, I guess, of me saying that discovering cool stuff in D&D or other role playing games and that feeling that you get when you make a discovery or are around when someone else you know makes a cool discovery fostered in me a desire to go learn about other cool stuff outside of role playing games, because sometimes its even more fantastical than fantasy-land is.
Rangers suck

An expanded facility with reading, writing, art, science, and (especially) vocabulary are the most obvious things that D&D taught me. These are by far outweighed by the more useful ability to consider things from another person's point of view. Role-playing, after all, is a continuous exercise in imagining how another person might act and feel in a situation, and it is easy to extrapolate this into an improved empathy for others in day-to-day life.

I began playing D&D as an adult, so I had already learnt many of the social skills and behaviours that you are alluding to, but I have learned to manage social situations to reflect the desired outcomes shared by many in a collaborative game. As a GM, organising and playing D&D has been a constant reminder to me to be aware of others and to take responsibility for my actions.As a relatively inexperienced GM I've learned that narratives can not be treated in the same way in different mediums. When I made a particular blunder of depriving my players of agency in a kobayashi maru type scenario I understod the frustrations of my players and sided with them by doubling my efforts to improve their experience of the game. As a player, I've learned to immediately deal with a conflict of interest by calmly explaining any issues and asking for empathy, even if other players do no concede to reasons unless they too have felt negatively affected.On a more general note, organising D&D has drastically improved my time management and organisational skills.

I started running games at age 7. I have strong language skills, strong math skills, and a deep understanding of story structure. In school I knew more words than others, and when studies turned to mythology and medieval history, I found I had already learned those things. In science I found I was ahead because I had adjudicated fires and explosions, time and distance, weather effects, etc. Having first used multiplication, fractions, and calculation of averages in play, I ended up with a degree in mathematics. Most importantly, I am able to organize and lead groups of people, which every Dungeon Master must do if they are to run games.

I have learned to become a better speaker/orator in all forms, especially with regards to choosing the words that I use when I speak with others (that is, I use much more precise wording, especially when describing past events and my own thoughts and feelings). I have also become better at adapting to unexpected social situations effectively, including when I am asked difficult or unexpected questions or when a tense social situation needs to be diffused (e.g., being able to reduce tension when the potential for quarreling between people occurs).

Tabletop games have given me everything! It's all of my hobbies mashed together. If I get bored of writing a new story for my players, I can work on painting miniatures or building scenery for the table. If I get bored of that I can create new NPCs for the campaign. It's given me such a huge creative outlet that I wouldn't have anywhere else.

As a director/animator, it helps me excersice my understanding of character dynamics in a fun and compelling way. It allows me to develope characters, loveable and hated, and gives me the opportunity to look at the outside perspective of what others may find a compelling character to be. Also, as an introvert, it really helps to get me out of my comfort zone and project myself more, be that astounding others with fantastic ideas or knocking em dead when I make a fool of myself. I have confidence in myself and can feel comfortable in either case.

Being primarily a DM, D&D has helped me with my creativity, my writing ability, my improvisational ability, as well as my ability to communicate with my friends and players about issues they are having.

I've learned to do math quicker in my head - I have dyscalculia and so mental math requires significant effort for even single digit addition. Having to add dice together all the time has improved my ability to do so fairly significantly, to the point where other people are capable of noticing it. I still get it wrong or run across numbers I just can't add together or divide (resistance/saves), but overall its improved considerably.
